image.altText: Pedestrians

items.synopsis: Australia's economy grew by 0.2 per cent in the March quarter, slower than economists were expecting, dragging the annual rate down to just 2.3 per cent.

title.children: ‘Lowest household saving in 15 years’: Australia’s economy grows by only 0.2pc in March quarter

image.altText: Empty retail strip in Sydney CBD, artistic shot from low down along pavement.

items.synopsis: Australia's economy is close to stall speed, with growth disappointing in the March quarter. RBA governor Philip Lowe defends the bank's decision to raise rates yesterday. Follow the day's events and send your questions to our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Your questions answered as economic growth stalls while RBA governor defends rate hike, ASX treads water

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just a reminder, comments are open and you can use the little blue button to ask us your questions about today's GDP data or RBA governor Philip Lowe's latest speech. Don't be shy, and we'll try to get to as many as we can.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Taking questions on GDP and interest rates

children.content: Just a reminder, comments are open and you can use the little blue button to ask us your questions about today's GDP data or RBA governor Philip Lowe's latest speech.
Don't be shy, and we'll try to get to as many as we can.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Federal treasurer Jim Chalmers is commenting on the GDP figures. He says the figures are not surprising, but show the impact of higher interest rates and a slowing global economy. "The rise in interest rates is clearly biting," he said. "We see that in the numbers because households are pulling back on spending, they are saving less and paying more in interest." "Household consumption eased for the third quarter in a row, it grew by just 0.2 per cent in the quarter and that's because households pulled back on discretionary spending to make room for the essentials in their household budget." "The saving ratio fell to 3.7 per cent, and that's the lowest since 2008." " Mortgage interest expenses have doubled over the course of the last year." But Mr Chalmers noted that wages have increased, even though they are being outstripped by inflation. "One of the pleasing aspects of these numbers is that household incomes grew solidly in the quarter at the same time as price pressures in the economy were moderating." "If you look at the wages and salaries number, it rose by 2.4 per cent in the quarter and 10.8 per cent over the year and that's because more Australians are in jobs."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer: interest rates are biting

children.content: Federal treasurer Jim Chalmers is commenting on the GDP figures.
He says the figures are not surprising, but show the impact of higher interest rates and a slowing global economy.
"The rise in interest rates is clearly biting," he said.
"We see that in the numbers because households are pulling back on spending, they are saving less and paying more in interest."

"Household consumption eased for the third quarter in a row, it grew by just 0.2 per cent in the quarter and that's because households pulled back on discretionary spending to make room for the essentials in their household
budget."
"The saving ratio fell to 3.7 per cent, and that's the lowest since 2008."
" Mortgage interest expenses have doubled over the course of the last year."
But Mr Chalmers noted that wages have increased, even though they are being outstripped by inflation.
"One of the pleasing aspects of these numbers is that household incomes grew solidly in the quarter at the same time as price pressures in the economy were moderating."
"If you look at the wages and salaries number, it rose by 2.4 per cent in the quarter and 10.8 per cent over the year and that's because more Australians are in jobs."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has run out of steam after the latest GDP figures showed that high interest rates and the cost of living were taking their toll on the economy. The ASX 200 is flat at lunchtime and the Australian dollar has also run out of steam, after yesterday's big rise. Investors are bracing for more interest rate rises after the Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe said inflation was too high and more interest rate rises were expected. Most sectors are higher on the benchmark index with education firms, industrials and healthcare leading the gains. All the big banks have lost ground but big miners are higher because of a rise in iron ore prices. Medical device maker Polynovo (+11 per cent) is leading the gains on record sales, but oil firm Beach Energy (-6.7 per cent) is leading the falls.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets loses gains after GDP figures

children.content: The Australian share market has run out of steam after the latest GDP figures showed that high interest rates and the cost of living were taking their toll on the economy.
The ASX 200 is flat at lunchtime and the Australian dollar has also run out of steam, after yesterday's big rise.
Investors are bracing for more interest rate rises after the Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe said inflation was too high and more interest rate rises were expected.
Most sectors are higher on the benchmark index with education firms, industrials and healthcare leading the gains.
All the big banks have lost ground but big miners are higher because of a rise in iron ore prices.
Medical device maker Polynovo (+11 per cent) is leading the gains on record sales, but oil firm Beach Energy (-6.7 per cent) is leading the falls.

props.alt: Best and worst performers on ASX 200

children.content: ASX top movers
(Refinitiv)

image.altText: A satellite image shows Nova Kakhovka Dam in Kherson.

items.synopsis: On the morning the Nova Kakhokva dam was blown up in southern Ukraine, resident Hanna Zarudnia woke to both shelling and flooding. Then she was "surrounded by water from all sides".

title.children: 'The volume of water is colossal': The moment a Ukrainian dam was destroyed and the war changed forever

image.altText: A white luxury boat on the ocean

items.synopsis: A 53.5m luxury superyacht was sold earlier this year to pay back debts to international creditors, but more than $4 million owed to customers is unlikely to be returned.

title.children: Customers $4 million out of pocket after cruise company collapse

image.altText: A young man in a blue t-shirt speaks while an Indonesian officer watches

items.synopsis: The family of an Australian man accused of a drunken, naked rampage in Indonesia has thanked everyone involved in the deal to free him as he makes his way home.

title.children: Australian tourist 'looking forward to putting this chapter behind him' after alleged drunken rampage

image.altText: Couple face away from the camera and look at a phone in the middle of them.

items.synopsis: Needle spiking is when a person is injected with a drug without their consent, and it's unknown how much it's happening in Australian venues.

title.children: Two friends blacked out while at a bar. Then they found the needle prick

image.altText: Lightning across a dark sky on a beach with a jetty

items.synopsis: In a complete reverse of the cold pattern of southerly winds in May, we are now seeing one of the warmest starts to winter on record.

title.children: Unseasonable storms bring warmest start to Australian winter in decades

image.altText: Water bottles and garbage float on the surface of water

items.synopsis: A marine waste collection company says there has been a significant reduction in plastic bags recovered from the harbour. But one big issue still needs to be addressed.

title.children: 'Staggering' fall in plastic bags polluting Sydney Harbour — but there's still much to do

image.altText: Two Bitcoins held in both hands with a Binance price chart opened in the background.

items.synopsis: The cryptocurrency industry has long argued tokens do not constitute a "security", however the results of cases against Binance and Coinbase could change that.

title.children: Crypto crackdown by US securities could transform the industry

image.altText: Katy Gallagher wearing a black jacket and purple top, looking to the right

items.synopsis: Ministers say a recent decision to substantially lift the minimum wage is not behind yesterday's rate hike, but some economists disagree, and the opposition says it is time the government stops searching for others to blame.

title.children: Ministers deflect blame for latest interest rate hike, pointing to war in Ukraine — not minimum wage rise

image.altText: Golfing great Jack Nicklaus stands at a lectern with microphones in front of him.

items.synopsis: Reactions to the merger, range from joy and relief to frustration and even fury, with some accusing golf's leaders of choosing money and giving up their principles.

title.children: LIV-PGA merger … good for the game, or 'one of the saddest days in golf'?

image.altText: An Australian boxer in a gold national top smiles as he holds up an Olympic bronze medal around his neck.

items.synopsis: The Tokyo Olympics bronze medallist says the ordeal has been personally devastating, as he prepares for qualification for the 2024 Paris Games.

title.children: Domestic assault charges dropped against Oympic boxer Harry Garside

image.altText: Aerial view of a bushfire at night time

items.synopsis: An army major tells an inquiry into a destructive bushfire south of Canberra in 2020 he may not have authorised a helicopter to land for a crew member's toilet break if he had been asked.

title.children: Army major tells bushfire inquiry he may not have approved 'whiz break' that led to massive blaze

image.altText: A man in blue top outside a court building. A woman looks on behind him

items.synopsis: An Adelaide truck driver who was involved in a crash that injured two school students has appeared in court for the first time on two counts of dangerous driving.

title.children: Truck driver who allegedly struck two schoolchildren at pedestrian crossing faces court

image.altText: Police vehicles and crime scene tape at a home at Narangba, north of Brisbane.

items.synopsis: Shaun Sturgess is on trial for the domestic violence murder of his estranged wife Jacqueline in April 2020.

title.children: Man who 'clubbed' estranged wife over the head with 1.8kg sledgehammer pleads not guilty to murder

image.altText: Wide shot exterior of Lamb House

items.synopsis: It has taken more than two years and the spend has ballooned well beyond the original estimate, but this passion project is almost complete and the owners are excited.

title.children: Two years after buying dilapidated Lamb House, the Wilsons are just months away from moving in

image.altText: RBA governor Philip Lowe speaks at the Morgan Stanley Australia summit in Sydney

items.synopsis: Take one for the team. That is essentially the message Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe has delivered to the millions of Australians faced with surging mortgage repayments.

title.children: Lowe says threat of inflation trumps mortgage pain when setting rates

image.altText: A female Aedes aegypti mosquito bites someone's skin.

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory has recorded seven cases and two deaths from Murray Valley encephalitis (MVE) this year, as the health department urges people to protect themselves against mosquito bites.

title.children: Outbreak of mosquito-borne disease in the NT sparks health warning

image.altText: A decrepit small one-storey building with pale yellow paint peeling off

items.synopsis: Residents in regional and rural Queensland are crying out for basic upgrades to what have been labelled unacceptable hospital conditions, some 140 years old.

title.children: 'Maggots were falling from the ceiling': Outback residents demand hospital upgrades

image.altText: A large concrete sign with letters saying National Gallery of Australia.

items.synopsis: The National Gallery of Australia has indefinitely shelved a controversial exhibition of artworks from South Australia's APY Lands.

title.children: National Gallery of Australia formally postpones exhibition featuring APY artwork

image.altText: Two firefighters in full protective equipment use a fire hose on burning scrub as smoke billows through nearby trees.

items.synopsis: A merger between Tasmania Fire Service and the State Emergency Service has drawn criticism, with former fire chiefs saying it will create "dangerous" levels of bureaucracy. Last week, the TFS chief officer quit his post over the concerns.

title.children: Former fire chiefs fear 'dangerous' emergency reforms in lead up to next bushfire season

image.altText: An American saltwater crocodile opens its mouth underwater.

items.synopsis: An American crocodile managed to reproduce by herself, in a process scientists call parthenogenesis, or 'virgin birth', DNA reveals. Scientists say the discovery suggests the phenomenon may have also occurred in extinct reptiles like dinosaurs.

title.children: 'When all else fails': Female crocodile that lived alone for 16 years had a 'virgin birth'

image.altText: A close-up of a man's face as he leaves court

items.synopsis: The 22-year-old was charged over the weekend after he was accused of groping a woman at a Double Bay venue in Sydney's eastern suburbs.

title.children: Lawyer for NRL star Dylan Brown says CCTV 'does not' support groping allegations

image.altText: Cattle walk over a huge mountain of landfill, mostly comprised of old clothes.

items.synopsis: Australia's biggest fashion retailers are being threatened with a mandatory levy on garment sales, after many big names failed to sign up to a new scheme to tackle the 200,000 tonnes of old clothes going into landfill each year.

title.children: Just six Australian fashion giants sign up to a scheme to tackle their industry's waste problem

image.altText: A close up shot of a woman holing and looking at her newborn baby in a hospital bed.

items.synopsis: Women of migrant backgrounds are more at risk of developing some pregnancy complications, which can limit their choices for their pregnancy care and lead to more medical interventions during birth.

title.children: Caitlin planned for a water birth, but a diagnosis in labour changed everything

image.altText: A pair of hands prepares to tear up a piece of paper labelled "reward for experience".

items.synopsis: A campaign designed to kill off the government's proposed "same job, same pay" changes has been launched. So what do we know about what the government is looking to achieve?

title.children: Same job, same pay: A matter of fairness or a 'dangerous' attack on business?

image.altText: Headshot photo of smiling Andrew Heard.

items.synopsis: The grim details of a fatal crocodile attack on a fisherman in Far North Queensland have been revealed following a coronial investigation into his death.

title.children: Fisherman's death first known case of two crocodiles consuming a human, department finds

image.altText: Wayne Smith photo at port

items.synopsis: NSW Police confirmed that the man at the centre of a suspected murder suicide in northern New South Wales had his gun licence revoked sometime in 2022.

title.children: Father in suspected murder-suicide had gun licence previously suspended

image.altText: David Koutsouridis with a sign, wearing sunglasses, people holding signs behind him at the writers strike picket lines

items.synopsis: An Australian comedy writer based in Los Angeles says the Hollywood writers' strike is a serious matter that will have implications for the global entertainment industry.

title.children: 'The whole system is about to fall apart': Aussie writer in LA raises alarm as strike continues

image.altText: Cassie Siataga

items.synopsis: The Samoan fly-half has pulled off a penalty kick to win Manusina's first-ever regional title, snatching the championship away from Fiji, but she has also scored every point for her team's victory.

title.children: Cassie Siataga's kick to go down in Samoan rugby history

image.altText: A sketch of prince harry sitting in front of a microphone in a courtroom

items.synopsis: Prince Harry is grilled in court as the Mirror Newspaper Group's legal team seeks to discredit his allegations that its journalists engaged in unlawful information-gathering practices to publish stories about him.

title.children: Prince Harry doubles down on 'incredibly suspicious' Mirror articles as he is cross examined in court
